column2: And Mrs. Billy glanced about her at the exquisite assemblage in Mrs. Devon's Louis Seize drawing-room.
column3: And mrs Billy glanced about her at the exquisite assemblage in mrs Devon's Louis Seize drawing room.

column2: What do you suppose these people are here for to-night? she asked.
column3: What do you suppose these people are here for to night? she asked.

column2: CHAPTER IX
column3: CHAPTER nine

column2: A weekor two had passed, when one day Oliver called his brother on the 'phone.
column3: A weekor two had passed, when one day Oliver called his brother on the 'phone.

column2: Have you or Alice any engagement this evening? he asked.
column3: Have you or Alice any engagement this evening? he asked.

column2: I want to bring a friend around to dinner.
column3: I want to bring a friend around to dinner.

column2: Who is it? inquired Montague.
column3: Who is it? inquired Montague.

column2: Nobody you have heard of, said Oliver.
column3: Nobody you have heard of, said Oliver.

column2: But I want you to meet him.	But I want you to meet him.
column3: true

column2: You will think he's rather queer, but I will explain to you afterwards.
column3: You will think he's rather queer, but I will explain to you afterwards.

column2: Tell Alice to take my word for him."
column3: Tell Alice to take my word for him."

column2: Montague delivered the message, and at seven o'clock they went downstairs.
column3: Montague delivered the message, and at seven o'clock they went downstairs.

column2: In the reception room they met Oliver and his friend, and it was all that Montague could do to repress a look of consternation.
column3: In the reception room they met Oliver and his friend, and it was all that Montague could do to repress a look of consternation.

column2: The name of the personage was Mr. Gamble.
column3: The name of the personage was mr Gamble.

column2: He was a little man, a trifle over five feet high, and so fat that one wondered how he could get about alone; his chin and neck were a series of rolls of fat.
column3: He was a little man, a trifle over five feet high, and so fat that one wondered how he could get about alone; his chin and neck were a series of rolls of fat.

column2: His face was round like a full moon, and out of it looked two little eyes like those of a pig.
column3: His face was round like a full moon, and out of it looked two little eyes like those of a pig.

column2: It was only after studying them for a while that one discovered that they twinkled shrewdly.
column3: It was only after studying them for a while that one discovered that they twinkled shrewdly.

column2: Mr. Gamble was altogether the vulgarest-looking personage that Alice Montague had ever met.
column3: mr Gamble was altogether the vulgarest looking personage that Alice Montague had ever met.

column2: He put out a fat little hand to her, and she touched it gingerly, and then gazed at Oliver and his brother in helpless dismay.
column3: He put out a fat little hand to her, and she touched it gingerly, and then gazed at Oliver and his brother in helpless dismay.

column2: Good evening.	Good evening.

column2: Good evening," he began volubly.
column3: Good evening," he began volubly.

column2: I am charmed to meet you.	I am charmed to meet you.

column2: Mr. Montague, I have heard so much about you from your brother that I feel as if we were old friends."
column3: mr Montague, I have heard so much about you from your brother that I feel as if we were old friends."

column3: There was a moment's pause.

column2: Shall we go into the dining-room? asked Montague.
column3: Shall we go into the dining room? asked Montague.

column2: He did not much relish the stares which would follow them, but he could see no way out of the difficulty.
column3: He did not much relish the stares which would follow them, but he could see no way out of the difficulty.

column3: They went into the room and seated themselves, Montague wondering in a flash whether mr Gamble's arms would be long enough to reach to the table in front of him.

column2: A warm evening, he said, puffing slightly.
column3: A warm evening, he said, puffing slightly.

column2: I have been on the train all day.
column3: I have been on the train all day.

column2: Mr. Gamble comes from Pittsburg, interposed Oliver.
column3: mr Gamble comes from Pittsburg, interposed Oliver.

column2: Indeed? said Montague, striving to make conversation.
column3: Indeed? said Montague, striving to make conversation.

column2: Are you in business there?
column3: Are you in business there?

column2: No, I am out of business, said Mr. Gamble, with a smile.
column3: No, I am out of business, said mr Gamble, with a smile.

column2: Made my pile, so to speak, and got out.	Made my pile, so to speak, and got out.

column2: I want to see the world a bit before I get too old."
column3: I want to see the world a bit before I get too old."

column3: The waiter came to take their orders; in the meantime Montague darted an indignant glance at his brother, who sat and smiled serenely.

column2: Then Montague caught Alice's eye, and he could almost hear her saying to him, "What in the world am I going to talk about?"
column3: Then Montague caught Alice's eye, and he could almost hear her saying to him, "What in the world am I going to talk about?"

column2: But it proved not very difficult to talk with the gentleman from Pittsburg.
column3: But it proved not very difficult to talk with the gentleman from Pittsburg.

column3: He appeared to know all the gossip of the Metropolis, and he cheerfully supplied the topics of conversation.

column2: He had been to Palm Beach and Hot Springs during the winter, and told about what he had seen there; he was going to Newport in the summer, and he talked about the prospects there.
column3: He had been to Palm Beach and Hot Springs during the winter, and told about what he had seen there; he was going to Newport in the summer, and he talked about the prospects there.

column3: If he had the slightest suspicion of the fact that all his conversation was not supremely interesting to Montague and his cousin, he gave no hint of it.

column2: After he had disposed of the elaborate dinner which Oliver ordered, Mr. Gamble proposed that they visit one of the theatres.
column3: After he had disposed of the elaborate dinner which Oliver ordered, mr Gamble proposed that they visit one of the theatres.

column2: He had a box all ready, it seemed, and Oliver accepted for Alice before Montague could say a word for her.
column3: He had a box all ready, it seemed, and Oliver accepted for Alice before Montague could say a word for her.

column2: He spoke for himself, however,--he had important work to do, and must be excused.
column3: He spoke for himself, however,--he had important work to do, and must be excused.

column2: He went upstairs and shook off his annoyance and plunged into his work.
column3: He went upstairs and shook off his annoyance and plunged into his work.

column2: Sometime after midnight, when he had finished, he went out for a breath of fresh air, and as he returned he found Oliver and his friend standing in the lobby of the hotel.
column3: Sometime after midnight, when he had finished, he went out for a breath of fresh air, and as he returned he found Oliver and his friend standing in the lobby of the hotel.

column2: How do you do, Mr. Montague? said Gamble.
column3: How do you do, mr Montague? said Gamble.

column2: Glad to see you again.
column3: Glad to see you again.

column2: Alice has just gone upstairs, said Oliver.
column3: Alice has just gone upstairs, said Oliver.

column2: We were going to sit in the cafe awhile.	We were going to sit in the cafe awhile.

column2: Will you join us?"
column3: Will you join us?"

column2: Yes, do, said Mr. Gamble, cordially.
column3: Yes, do, said mr Gamble, cordially.

column2: Montague went because he wanted to have a talk with Oliver before he went to bed that night.
column3: Montague went because he wanted to have a talk with Oliver before he went to bed that night.

column2: Do you know Dick Ingham? asked Mr. Gamble, as they seated themselves at a table.
column3: Do you know Dick Ingham? asked mr Gamble, as they seated themselves at a table.

column2: The Steel man, you mean? asked Montague.
column3: The Steel man, you mean? asked Montague.

column2: No, I never met him.
column3: No, I never met him.

column2: We were talking about him, said the other.
column3: We were talking about him, said the other.

column2: Poor chap--it really was hard luck, you know.	Poor chap-it really was hard luck, you know.
column3: true

column2: It wasn't his fault.
column3: It wasn't his fault.

column2: Did you ever hear the true story?"
column3: Did you ever hear the true story?"

column2: No, said Montague, but he knew to what the other referred.
column3: No, said Montague, but he knew to what the other referred.

column2: Ingham was one of the "Steel crowd," as they were called, and he had been president of the Trust until a scandal had forced his resignation.
column3: Ingham was one of the "Steel crowd," as they were called, and he had been president of the Trust until a scandal had forced his resignation.

column2: He is an old friend of mine, said Gamble; "he told me all about it.
column3: He is an old friend of mine, said Gamble; "he told me all about it.

column2: It began in Paris--some newspaper woman tried to blackmail him, and he had her put in jail for three months.
column3: It began in Paris-some newspaper woman tried to blackmail him, and he had her put in jail for three months.

column2: And when she got out again, then the papers at home began to get stories about poor Ingham's cutting up.
column3: And when she got out again, then the papers at home began to get stories about poor Ingham's cutting up.

column2: And the public went wild, and they made him resign--just imagine it!"
column3: And the public went wild, and they made him resign-just imagine it!"

column3: Gamble chuckled so violently that he was seized by a coughing spell, and had to signal for a glass of water.

column2: They've got a new scandal on their hands now, said Oliver.
column3: They've got a new scandal on their hands now, said Oliver.

column3: They're a lively crowd, the Steel fellows, laughed the other. "They want to make Davidson resign, too, but he'll fight them.

column2: He knows too much!
column3: He knows too much!

column2: You should hear his story!"
column3: You should hear his story!"

column3: I imagine it's not a very savoury one, said Montague, for lack of something to say.

column3: It's too bad, said the other, earnestly.

column3: I remember Davidson one night: 'Jim,' says he, 'a fellow gets a whole lot of money, and he buys him everything he wants, until at last he buys a woman, and then his trouble begins.

column2: If you're buying pictures, there's an end to it--you get your walls covered sooner or later.

column2: But you never can satisfy a woman.'" And Mr. Gamble shook his head.

column2: Too bad, too bad, he repeated.

column2: I've been fighting the Trust, and last year they bought me out, and now I'm seeing the world."

column3: I never went in for that sort of thing myself, he said meditatively; "I am a married man, I am, and one woman is enough for me."

column2: Is your family in New York? asked Montague, in an effort to change the subject.

column2: No, no, they live in Pittsburg, was the answer.

column3: Oliver, he asked, "what in the devil does this mean?"

column2: ONE day, a month or so later, Montague, to his great surprise, received a letter from Stanley Ryder.
column3: ONE day, a month or so later, Montague, to his great surprise, received a letter from Stanley Ryder.

column3: Could you make it convenient to call at my office sometime this afternoon? it read.
